1: <sup>1</sup> Through desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh and intermeddleth with all wisdom.
2: <sup>2</sup> A fool hath no delight in understanding, but that his heart may discover itself.
3: <sup>3</sup> When the wicked cometh, then cometh also contempt, and with ignominy reproach.
4: <sup>4</sup> The words of a man’s mouth are as deep waters, and the wellspring of wisdom as a flowing brook.
5: <sup>5</sup> It is not good to accept the person of the wicked, to overthrow the righteous in judgment.
6: <sup>6</sup> A fool’s lips enter into contention, and his mouth calleth for strokes.
7: <sup>7</sup> A fool’s mouth is his destruction, and his lips are the snare of his soul.
8: <sup>8</sup> The words of a talebearer are as wounds, and they go down into the innermost parts of the belly.
9: <sup>9</sup> He also that is slothful in his work is brother to him that is a great waster.
10: <sup>10</sup> The name of the LORD is a strong tower: the righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
11: <sup>11</sup> The rich man’s wealth is his strong city, and as an high wall in his own conceit.
12: <sup>12</sup> Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, and before honour is humility.
13: <sup>13</sup> He that answereth a matter before he heareth it, it is folly and shame unto him.
14: <sup>14</sup> The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; but a wounded spirit who can bear?
15: <sup>15</sup> The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; and the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
16: <sup>16</sup> A man’s gift maketh room for him, and bringeth him before great men.
17: <sup>17</sup> He that is first in his own cause seemeth just; but his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.
18: <sup>18</sup> The lot causeth contentions to cease, and parteth between the mighty.
19: <sup>19</sup> A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city: and their contentions are like the bars of a castle.
20: <sup>20</sup> A man’s belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth; and with the increase of his lips shall he be filled.
21: <sup>21</sup> Death and life are in the power of the tongue: and they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
22: <sup>22</sup> Whoso findeth a wife findeth a good thing, and obtaineth favour of the LORD.
23: <sup>23</sup> The poor useth intreaties; but the rich answereth roughly.
24: <sup>24</sup> A man that hath friends must shew himself friendly: and there is a friend that sticketh closer than a brother.
